Phloxine B (PHB) demonstrates strong catalytic performance in cross-dehydrogenative coupling (CDC) reactions, yet its light-harvesting efficiency remains limited. Dye-supported nanofiber photocatalysts were developed via electrospinning, integrating polyvinyl alcohol (PVA), polydimethyldiallyl ammonium chloride (PDADMAC), and the Förster resonance energy transfer (FRET) pair: AY184 (donor) and PHB (acceptor). Four strategies—electrospinning-adsorption, blending-electrospinning, co-electrospinning from a single nozzle, and co-electrospinning from separate nozzles—were explored to optimize dye distribution and FRET efficiency. Among the synthesized nanofibers, the NF-TZ, co-electrospun from a single nozzle, showed the highest FRET efficiency at 59 %. The blended-electrospinning nanofibers (NF-GH) exhibited exceptional catalytic activity, achieving nearly 90 % conversion of N-phenyltetrahydroisoquinoline (N-phenyl-THIQ) within 4 hours under the visible light (1 W), and the reaction rate constant is 1.8-fold faster than that for fiber with PHB alone. For NF-GH, the conversion of N-phenyl-THIQ retained to 85 % with reused 7 times, demonstrating robust recyclability and photostability. This finding provides new insight into the construction of recyclable FRET-enhanced photocatalysts with broad spectral response and high energy conversion efficiency for organic photochemical reactions. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Förster resonance energy transfer (FRET) Nanofibers Photocatalysts Cross-dehydrogenative coupling reactions Phloxine B Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Sunlight represents a pristine and sustainable energy resource, and the investigation of photocatalytic processes harnessing solar energy aligns with the principles of green and sustainable development. Visible light photocatalytic reactions are an important class of reactions in organic chemistry, with the advantages of mild reaction conditions, environmental protection, high efficiency and economy [1–8]. Among them, the cross-dehydrogenation coupling (CDC) reaction has been widely used as an important organic synthesis method to activate and directly functionalize inert CH bonds [9–11]. Enhancing the efficiency of photocatalysts is a formidable challenge. A substantial number of photocatalysts have a limited capacity to absorb visible light. Additionally, the rapid recombination of photogenerated electrons and holes is a common issue. These limitations diminish their efficacy in practical applications [12]. To overcome these limitations, a variety of strategies have been explored, including novel photosensitive materials like hydrogel [13] and semiconductor [14], design of special photocatalytic structures like bilayer structure [15] and metallacage [16], the use of Förster resonance energy transfer (FRET) [17–19]. FRET process is a non-radiative energy transfer between molecules. It relies on the transfer of energy between two fluorescent molecules: a donor (Donor) and an acceptor (Acceptor). The FRET happens when the emission spectrum of the donor overlaps with the absorption spectrum of the acceptor and the distance is close enough (usually <10 nm) [20]. In a FRET system, when a donor molecule is excited by light, the energy will be non-radiatively transfered to a nearby acceptor molecule, leading to reduced fluorescence in the donor and increased fluorescence in the acceptor. FRET plays a vital part in photocatalytic systems by enabling the effective separation and use of charges generated by light through non-radiative energy transfer mechanisms [21]. Common donor-acceptor pairs include the following. (1) The dye-to-dye pair involves a photosensitive dye, exemplified by Rhodamine, that captures light energy and becomes excited. The acceptor, such as Rose Bengal, receives this energy [17,18]. (2) The organic-to-inorganic pair involves utilizing organic small molecules or polymers with significant light absorption properties as the donor, inorganic semiconductors such as ZnO and TiO2 as the acceptor. By absorbing light in a diverse wavelength spectrum, organic molecules can effectively transfer energy to inorganic semiconductors through the FRET process, leading to improved charge separation and transfer [22,23]. (3) The metal-to-dye pair involves utilizing metal nanoparticles as the donor, fluorescent dyes as the acceptor. The unique optical properties of metal nanoparticles, specifically gold (Au) and silver (Ag), enable them to interact with fluorescent dyes through localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR), thus allowing for non-radiative energy transfer [24,25]. (4) The supramolecular-to-catalyst approach involves utilizing a macromolecular structure as the donor, paired with photocatalyst as the acceptor. A macromolecular entity arises from self-assembly via non-covalent interactions, serving as the donor, while the acceptor consists of a photocatalyst that is anchored onto the self-assembled framework. The organized arrangement created by self-assembly fosters a systematic setting that enhances both the effectiveness and precision of energy transfer processes [26,27]. In summary, FRET plays a crucial role in photocatalysis by widening the light absorption capabilities of photocatalysts, lowering the likelihood of electron-hole complex formation, and enhancing the efficiency of charge separation. Additionally, FRET mitigates the degradation of photocatalysts during prolonged illumination and boosts the overall efficiency of photocatalytic reactions. In addition to the utilisation of FRET, the selection of a suitable carrier can also be beneficial in enhancing the effectiveness of the catalyst. During CDC processes, some photocatalysts can experience photocorrosion when exposed to light for extended periods, resulting in a decline in their structural integrity and effectiveness. The rapid complexation of photogenerated carriers (electrons and holes) reduces the number of carriers available for catalysing the reaction, affecting the catalytic efficiency and long-term stability [28]. Additionally, the efficacy of specific photocatalysts declines with multiple uses, which stems from changes in their structural integrity, the inactivation of active sites on their surfaces, or the influence of contaminants. The effectiveness and financial viability of photocatalysts hinge significantly on two key elements: their durability under light exposure and their ability to be utilized multiple times. To solve this problem, catalysts have been chosen to be immobilized on carriers such as metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [29,30], covalent organic frameworks (COFs) [31,32], nanoparticles (NPs) [33,34], carbon nanotubes [35], polyamides [36], foams [37], microcrystalline cellulose [38], sponges [39] and so on. Despite their advantages, these catalyst carriers face issues like separation challenges, limited surface area, and insufficient catalytic efficiency, failing to fulfill the need for effective catalytic materials. Fiber has the advantages of large specific surface area, easy to obtain and easy to recover, which can be used as an ideal catalyst carrier. In our previous study, cotton fibers with a large specific surface area were used as the support material for the CDC reaction, which showed excellent catalytic performance and could be easily recycled and reused five times [9]. In addition, the electrostatically spun nanofibers were found to have a larger specific surface area, by which we prepared a nanofiber-based photocatalyst for the CDC reaction. The catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic activity and good reusability for the CDC reaction under visible light, while overcoming the challenges of catalyst separation and recovery in conventional homogeneous catalytic systems [40]. However, the FRET strategy to improve the catalytic effect on larger specific surface area nanofibres as well has not been attempted. Therefore, in this study, AY184-PHB nanofiber photocatalysts were prepared using poly(vinyl alcohol) nanofibers as carriers and C.I. Acidic Yellow 184-phloxine B as a FRET donor-acceptor pair. In addition, The effects of distinct preparation processes on the nanofiber structure, distribution of dye molecules, and photocatalytic performance were explored. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Reagents and instruments Phloxine B (PHB), polyvinyl alcohol (PVA), ethanol, Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Science and Technology Co. Ltd.; C.I. Acid Yellow 184 (AY184), Zhejiang Longsheng Group Co. Ltd.; polydimethyl diallylammonium chloride (PDADMAC), Shanghai Macklin Science and Technology Co. Ltd.; N-phenyltetrahydroisoquinoline, acetonitrile, biphenyl, dimethylmalonate, Adamas Reagent Co. Ltd. WP-TEC-1020SL Photocatalytic Parallel Reactor, Xi'an Huatai Kosi Chemical Technology Co., Ltd; LC-1200 High Performance Liquid Chromatograph, Agilent, USA; FluoroMax-4/Plus Fluorescence Spectrometer, HORIBA Group, Japan; ET-2535DE Electrostatic Spinning Machine, Beijing Yongkang Leye Technology Development Co. Ltd. 2.2 Preparation of AY184-PHB nanofibers The preparation of AY184-PHB nanofibers was mainly achieved by four preparation processes (electrospinning-adsorption(NF-XF), blending- electrospinning(NF-GH), co-spinning from a single nozzle(NF-TZ), and co-spinning from separate nozzles(NF-GP)). The electrospinning-adsorption process involves the preparation of nanofibers containing only the acceptor dye PHB, and then the PVA-PHB nanofibers were put into the ethanol solution of AY184 for the adsorption of the dye AY184. The blending-electrospinning process involves mixing the donor dye AY184 and the acceptor dye PHB directly in the spinning solution, and then the electrostatic spinning equipment was used to achieve the preparation of AY184-PHB nanofibers. The process of co-spinning from a single nozzle involves the initial configuration of the donor dye AY184 and the acceptor dye PHB into separate spinning liquids, designated as spinning liquid a and spinning liquid b, respectively. Subsequently, these two components are merged to form a composite spinning solution within the specialized co-axial nozzle during the electrostatic spinning stage. This method is employed to fabricate Janus AY184-PHB nanofibers. The co-spinning from separate nozzles technique entails the individual preparation of the donor dye AY184 and the acceptor dye PHB into distinct spinning liquids, referred to as spinning liquid a and spinning liquid b, respectively. These two components are then subjected to electrostatic spinning via a peristaltic pump, and subsequently collected on a common roller. Spinning solution preparation and electrospinning process: PVA (1788) powder (0.9 g) and the cationic polymer PDADMAC (0.1 g) were added to deionized water and stirred under heating at 95 °C until a homogeneous, clear solution with a concentration of 10 wt% was obtained. After cooling the solution to room temperature, the fluorescent dye PHB was added and the mixture was stirred overnight to eliminate remaining air bubbles. The spinning solution was held using a 10 ml syringe equipped with a 21 gauge needle (inner diameter 0.5 mm). The supply rate, receiving distance and voltage were set at 0.4 mL/h (0.2 mL/h for co-spinning from the same nozzle), 15 cm and 14 kV, respectively. And the nanofibers were collected using a roller covered with silicone oil paper. The obtained nanofibers were heat-treated in a constant temperature blast drying oven at 50 °C for 12 h to remove residual solvent. 2.3 Photocatalytic oxidation of CDC As shown in Fig. 2 , the reaction between N-phenyltetrahydroisoquinoline and dimethyl malonate was chosen as a model reaction to evaluate the catalytic performance of AY184-PHB nanofibers. The photocatalytic experiments were carried out at 35 °C using a photocatalytic parallel reactor (WP-TEC-1200SL, WATTCAS), a rotational speed of 800 r/min, and a light source of a white LED 1 W. In the reaction, N-phenyltetrahydroisoquinoline (0.1 mmol), dimethyl malonate (1.0 mL), AY184-PHB nanofibers(catalyst) and biphenyl (0.1 mmol, internal standard) were suspended in 10 mL of ethanol. The reaction was monitored by HPLC. The conversion of N-phenyltetrahydroisoquinoline (Conv) was calculated according to the following equation: C o n v = ( 1 − A t / B t A 0 / B 0 ) × 100 % Conv (%) is the percentage conversion of N-phenyltetrahydroisoquinoline. At and Bt are the peak areas of the substrate and biphenyl at time t, respectively. A0 and B0 are the initial peak areas of the substrate and biphenyl, respectively. The photocatalytic kinetics can be characterized by the first-order model and calculated according to the following equation: L n ( 1 − Conv ) = k d t kd is the first-order rate constant which can be determined by the plot of ln(1-Con.) versus time t. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the AY184-PHB nanofiber photocatalyst The photographs of AY184-PHB nanofibers with different dye dosages under daylight are shown in Fig. 3 . With the increase of AY184 dosage, the colors of the nanofibers prepared by different processes showed a gradual shift from peach to deep red. In addition, the morphology and structure of the nanofibers prepared by different processes were characterised using scanning electron microscopy. The diameter of the nanofibers was statistically analysed. As shown in Fig. 4 , the SEM images revealed that the nanofibers prepared by different processes all have a great specific surface area and ultra-high porosity. Meanwhile, the diameter distribution plots of the nanofibers showed that the fiber diameters of NF-XF, NF-GH and NF-TZ were mainly distributed around 200–300 nm, whereas the fiber diameters of NF-GP were mainly distributed around 350–450 nm. The larger diameter of NF-GP is attributed to the stronger electric field force during the co-electrospinning from separate nozzles, which accelerates the jet motion and reduces the time for solvent evaporation and fiber refinement [41]. As a result, the specific surface area of the nanofiber NF-GP is smaller than the other three nanofibers. The chemical structure revealed that the elements contained were Br, Cl and S due to the addition of two dyes according to Fig. 5 . Br and Cl can be traced back to the fluorescent dye PHB and S to the fluorescent dye AY184. The EDS images clearly showed the uniform distribution of the three elements, i.e. the two fluorescent dyes are uniformly distributed on the nanofibres. This homogeneity was a key parameter as it ensured consistent performance and functionality. 3.2 Fluorescence intensity study of AY184-PHB nanofibers The fluorescence intensity of the nanofibers is an important index to evaluate their catalytic performance. The enhanced fluorescence intensity of PHB indicate that the amount of photoexcited, catalytically active species is increased. This role facilitates electron transfer between the photocatalyst and substrates, thereby accelerating the reaction rate and improving overall catalytic performance. A series of AY184-PHB nanofibers with different molar ratios of dye content were constructed by adjusting the amount of donor dye AY184 on the basis of controlling the same amount of acceptor dye PHB. The fluorescence intensity of the prepared series of AY184-PHB nanofibers was tested by fluorescence spectroscopy. 3.2.1 Effect of donor and acceptor molar ratio on the fluorescence intensity of nanofibers The fluorescence intensity of AY184-PHB nanofibers obtained from different preparation processes was tested and the results are shown in Fig. 6 . Nanofibers' fluorescence intensity was analyzed at the donor dye's peak excitation of 438 nm, with AY184 and PHB exhibiting maximum emissions at 506 nm and 586 nm. In exploring the effect of dye molar ratio PHB:AY184 on the fluorescence intensity of the nanofibers, the optimum amount of PHB (i.e., 0.05 mmol/g) for the CDC reaction was used for the dosage of PHB. The fluorescence intensity of the nanofiber NF-XF is shown in Fig. 6(a). The fluorescence emission intensity of the acceptor dye PHB was maximum when the molar ratio of PHB:AY184 in the nanofibers was 1:0.3, indicating that the FRET efficiency of the donor and acceptor dyes in the nanofibers at this time was the highest. Under these conditions, the amount of the donor dye AY184 was minimal. Despite the energy transfer process, the fluorescence did not vanish entirely. This persistence of fluorescence is attributed to the surface localization of dye AY184 on the nanofibers. Only a portion of the dye molecules engaged in the FRET (Förster Resonance Energy Transfer) process. The remaining dye molecules, which did not participate in FRET, emitted fluorescence. This emission occurred as the electrons transitioned back to the ground state through radiative pathways. As the amount of AY184 on the surface of the nanofibers was further increased, the fluorescence intensity of the acceptor dye PHB decreased instead. The primary reason for this phenomenon is that the dye AY184 predominantly adheres to the outer layer of the nanofibers. AY184 belongs to the ‘ACQ’ (Aggregation-caused Quenching) type of dyes. High concentration on the surface will lead to the donor dye AY184 molecules stacking with π-π interactions and fluorescence aggregation-caused quenching will occur. The high surface concentration will cause the molecules of the donor dye AY184 to stack in the way of π-π interactions and induce quenching of fluorescence aggregation. The fluorescence intensity of the nanofiber NF-GH is shown in Fig. 6(b). The fluorescence emission intensity of the acceptor dye PHB was maximum when the molar ratio of PHB:AY184 in the nanofibers was 1:0.5. As the amount of AY184 was further increased, the fluorescence intensity of both dye AY184 and PHB decreased, again attributable to the fluorescence aggregation-induced quenching phenomenon occurring in AY184. The dispersion of AY184 within the nanofibers was more uniform compared to NF-XF. This uniform distribution enabled the precise adjustment of the donor concentration. Consequently, this adjustment had a significant effect on enhancing the fluorescence intensity of the acceptor dyes. The fluorescence intensity of the nanofiber NF-TZ is shown in Fig. 6(c). The fluorescence emission intensity of the acceptor dye PHB was maximum when the molar ratio of PHB:AY184 in the nanofibers was 1:0.8. The fluorescence of AY184 in nanofibers prepared by co-spinning from the same nozzle showed the most significant decrease compared to other processes. This decrease in fluorescence suggests that the co-spinning process from the same nozzle enhances the energy transfer efficiency of AY184. Upon increasing the concentration of the donor dye AY184, the fluorescence intensity of the acceptor dye PHB decreased. This reduction in fluorescence intensity is attributed to a decrease in energy transfer efficiency. The decrease is caused by the fluorescence aggregation-caused quenching phenomenon that occurs in AY184. The fluorescence intensity of nanofiber NF-GP is shown in Fig. 6(d). The fluorescence emission intensity of the acceptor dye PHB is maximum when the PHB:AY184 molar ratio in the nanofiber NF-GP is 1:1.3. In the nanofibers prepared by co-spinning from different nozzles, the AY184 and PHB components are located on separate fibers. The large distance between these fibers makes energy transfer between the dyes more challenging. Consequently, the decrease in fluorescence intensity of the donor dye AY184 is not pronounced. In the absence of the ACQ (aggregation-caused quenching) phenomenon, a higher concentration of the donor dye AY184 facilitates energy transfer. Therefore, compared to other processes, a higher PHB:AY184 molar ratio is necessary for the acceptor dye PHB to achieve maximum fluorescence emission intensity in the nanofiber NF-GP. The effect of different preparation processes on the fluorescence intensity of AY184-PHB nanofibers under the optimum PHB:AY184 molar ratio is shown in Fig. 7 . The fluorescence intensities was affected by various factors, such as the structural composition of the fibers, the amount of donor dyes, and the spacing of the donor and acceptor dye molecules. Firstly, the nanofibers NF-TZ, NF-GH and NF-XF have closer intermolecular distances between donor and acceptor dye molecules than NF-GP. Under visible light irradiation, resonance is more likely to occur when dye molecules are at an appropriate distance. This resonance facilitates energy transfer, which in turn enhances the fluorescence intensity of the acceptor dye. Fig. 1 shows a schematic diagram of the distribution of dye molecules in the cross-section of nanofibers prepared by different processes, demonstrating the distribution of the donor dye AY184 and the acceptor dye PHB on the nanofibers. Secondly, the methods used for preparation affect the distribution of donor and acceptor dye molecules. The necessary dye concentration for the ACQ phenomenon to take place is established through these processes. As a result, diferent AY184:PHB molar ratios are required to achieve the best fluorescence intensity in nanofbers made by various preparation methods. 3.2.2 FRET efficiency measurement The FRET efficiency of AY184-PHB nanofibers prepared by different processes was determined at optimum AY184:PHB molar ratio. The FRET efficiency was calculated using three methods (donor quenching, acceptor sensitization and fluorescence lifetime decay). The fluorescence intensity as well as the fluorescence lifetime raw data of the AY184-PHB nanofibers are recorded in Table S2 in the Appendix, and the formula for calculating the FRET efficiency are given below: FRET efficiency ηET (AY184-PHB system): η E T = 1 1 + ( r / R 0 ) 6 = 1 − τ D A τ D = 1 − I D A I D = ( I D A − I A I D A ) ( ε A ε D ) (1) Determination by donor AY184 fluorescence intensity quenching (excitation at 438 nm, emission at 506 nm): η E T = 1 − I D A I D = 1 − I A Y 184 − P H B I A Y 184 where IAY184-PHB and IAY184 are the fluorescence intensities of AY184-PHB and AY184 at 506 nm upon excitation at 438 nm, respectively. (2) Determination by acceptor PHB sensititation (excitation at 438 nm, emission at 586 nm): η E T = ( I D A − I A I D A ) ( ε A ε D ) = ( I A Y 184 − P H B − I P H B I A Y 184 − P H B ) ( ε P H B ε A Y 184 ) where IAY184-PHB and IPHB are the fluorescence intensities of AY184-PHB and PHB (acceptor) at 586 nm upon excitation at 438 nm, respectively. εPHB and εAY184 are the molar extinction coefficients of the dyes PHB and AY184, which are 93,800 and 27,800, respectively. (3) Determination by donor AY184 fluorescence lifetime decay (excitation at 438 nm, τ e m i s s i o n at 506 nm): η E T = 1 − τ D A τ D = 1 − τ A Y 184 − P H B τ A Y 184 Where τ AY184-PHB and τ AY184 are the fluorescence lifetimes of AY184-PHB and AY184 (donor) at 506 nm under 438 nm excitation, respectively. The FRET efficiency within AY184-PHB nanofibers was calculated using three different methods, and the results are presented in Table S3. There are substantial differences in the calculated FRET efficiency values. These discrepancies are due to variations in how the dyes are linked within the nanofibers. Additionally, other factors could be influencing the fluorescence intensity and lifetime of the donor dyes. Among the three methods, the acceptor sensitization method is deemed more reliable for analyzing the energy transfer interactions between the dyes in the AY184-PHB nanofibers [42]. Specifically, nanofiber NF-TZ exhibited the highest FRET efficiency (ηET = 0.59), while nanofiber NF-GP demonstrated the lowest FRET efficiency (ηET = 0.21). In the context of Förster Resonance Energy Transfer (FRET), the efficiency is critically dependent on the distance between donor and acceptor molecules, their relative orientation, and the spectral overlap between the donor’s emission and the acceptor’s absorption spectra. The theoretical framework of FRET suggests that as the distance between the donor and acceptor exceeds the typical range of 1–10 nm, the efficiency of energy transfer declines exponentially. Furthermore, the orientation of the transition dipoles of the donor and acceptor molecules plays a crucial role; a more favorable alignment leads to higher FRET efficiency. In the nanofibers prepared in this study, the efficiency of FRET varies due to differences in the distribution and proximity of the donor (AY184) and acceptor (PHB) dyes within the fibers. For instance, in NF-TZ nanofibers, co-electrospinning from a single nozzle likely results in a more controlled and closer proximity between the donor and acceptor dyes, thereby enhancing FRET efficiency. In contrast, in NF-GP nanofibers, the use of separate nozzles in the co-electrospinning process may result in a greater average distance between the dyes, reducing the likelihood of efficient FRET and consequently lowering FRET efficiency. The specific structural characteristics of each fiber type, such as diameter and porosity, also influence efficiency by affecting the spatial arrangement of dye molecules and the accessibility of light to the active sites. 3.3 Investigation of catalytic performance The catalytic performance of AY184-PHB nanofibers was evaluated using the CDC reaction between N-phenyltetrahydroisoquinoline and dimethyl malonate as a model reaction. Controls A, B, and C in Table 1 refer to blank controls using the same preparation process of NF-XF/GH, NF-TZ, and NF-GP without the addition of donor dye AY184, respectively. In addition, in order to highlight the promoting effect of the donor dye AY184 on the catalytic performance of the acceptor dye PHB, the actual amount of the main catalyst PHB in the nanofibers used for the photocatalytic reaction was halved to only 0.025 mol% compared to the previous study. The cross-dehydrocoupling reaction of N-phenyltetrahydroisoquinoline with dimethyl malonate was used as a model reaction to evaluate the photocatalytic performance of AY184-PHB nanofibers prepared by different processes. In cross-dehydrogenative coupling (CDC) reactions, by-product formation—such as overoxidation of the α-carbon to a ketone—can occur under harsh oxidative conditions [43]. However, under the mild and efficient conditions employed in this study, the nucleophile rapidly traps the reactive intermediate, effectively suppressing such pathways. As a result, by-product formation is negligible. The experimental results are shown in Fig. 8 . The kinetics of the polymer catalyst-catalysed reaction between N-phenyltetrahydroisoquinoline and dimethyl malonate was also investigated and the first-order model was used to fit the experimental data. The photocatalytic reaction rate constants (Kd) can be obtained from the slopes of the first-order linear fitting curves in Fig. 8(b), and the results are recorded in Table S4 in the supplementary material. The photocatalytic performance of AY184-PHB nanofibers, produced through various methods, ranked as NF-GH, NF-XF, NF-TZ, and NF-GP from highest to lowest. The photocatalytic activity of the nanofibers during the catalytic reaction was mainly regulated by the excitation efficiency of the main catalyst, PHB. The excitation efficiency of PHB was mainly affected by two factors. One is the direct excitation efficiency of PHB by visible light, which is affected by the fiber structure and fiber dosage; the other is the promotion of PHB excitation by FRET effect, which is affected by the FRET efficiency. As shown in Fig. 7(a), the conversion of the substrate N-phenyltetrahydroisoquinoline can reach about 90 % after the catalytic CDC reaction under the light condition of nanofibers NF-XF and NF-GH for 4 h. Initially, the catalytic performance of nanofibers NF-XF and NF-GH was similar during the photocatalytic process; however, NF-XF experienced a minor decrease as the reaction continued. This is because the dye AY184 on the surface of the nanofibers obtained by dye adsorption underwent photobleaching, and its chromophore was destroyed and could not emit fluorescence, which led to a decrease in the FRET efficiency. The photocatalytic activity of the nanofibers NF-TZ and NF-GP had a large gap compared to the previous two, with <80 % conversion of the substrate N-phenyltetrahydroisoquinoline after 4 h of catalytic CDC reaction. The photocatalytic reaction rate constant (kd) is an important parameter describing the catalytic performance of photocatalysts, and a larger value indicates a faster catalytic rate and higher catalytic activity of the catalyst. As shown in Table S4 in the supplementary material, the photocatalytic reaction rate constants of nanofibers NF-GH, NF-XF, NF-TZ and NF-GP were enhanced by 1.67, 1.47, 1.15 and 1.07 times, respectively, compared with the control group. The results showed that the photocatalytic activities of AY184-PHB nanofibers prepared by several processes were all improved to a certain extent compared with those of the nanofibers containing only PHB, which well demonstrated the enhancement of the photocatalytic performance of nanofibers by the FRET effect. In particular, the donor-acceptor dye combination method of nanofiber NF-GH showed the most significant enhancement of the photocatalytic performance. Two main reasons explain this situation: one is that the required amount of nanofibers NF-TZ and NF-GP for the catalytic reaction is twice that of NF-XF and NF-GH, assuming the same level of acceptor dye is used. The reaction occurs within a confined quartz tube, resulting in a significant quantity of nanofibers that overlap, thereby diminishing the effectiveness of direct light excitation of the dye. In addition, the larger distance between the d-A dye molecules in the nanofibers NF-GP hinders energy transfer, resulting in a significantly reduced FRET efficiency. Especially, the fiber diameter of NF-GP is larger than the other three nanofibers, so the specific surface area is relatively smaller, which also plays a negative impact on the catalytic efficiency of nanofiber NF-GP. The photocatalytic reaction rate of NF-TZ nanofibers with different dosages was investigated. As shown in Fig. 9 , the halving of the amount of nanofiber NF-TZ at the same dosage of dye PHB led to a significant reduction in the CDC reaction rate. To ensure the same PHB loading, the concentration of dye PHB must be doubled when the number of fibers is halved. This high concentration of PHB is more susceptible to the ACQ effect. The ACQ effect leads to fluorescence quenching. Consequently, the photocatalytic performance of the nanofibers is severely weakened. When the quantity of nanofiber NF-TZ was halved, yet the concentration of dye PHB remained unchanged, the photocatalytic reaction rate decreased because of an insufficient catalyst presence. Therefore, nanofibers for photocatalytic reactions require appropriate dye loading concentration as well as suitable dosage. The proposed photocatalytic mechanism is systematically illustrated in Fig. 10 . Upon irradiation, the AY184 photosensitizer undergoes photoexcitation from its ground state (S₀) to an electronically excited state (S₁). Subsequently, a portion of the excited-state energy is efficiently transferred to the PHB catalyst through a Förster resonance energy transfer (FRET) process. Concurrently, PHB achieves its excited state (PHB*) through dual excitation pathways: direct photon absorption and energy transfer from the photosensitizer. In the crucial electron transfer step, the photoactivated PHB* initiates a single-electron transfer (SET) process with N-phenyltetrahydroisoquinoline (a), generating a radical cation intermediate (b) along with the reduced PHB species (PHB·−). The catalytic cycle is maintained through rapid electron transfer from PHB·− to molecular oxygen/nucleophilic agents, concomitantly regenerating the ground-state PHB while producing reactive oxygen species (O₂·−) and nucleophilic radicals (Nuc·−). The transient radical cation intermediate (b) undergoes spontaneous deprotonation within the reaction medium, yielding the key amine intermediate (c). In the final step, nucleophilic attack by Nuc·− on the α-carbon of intermediate (c) leads to the formation of the desired heterocyclic product (d) with complete regioselectivity. 3.4 Investigation of the photocatalytic reaction The nanofiber NF-GH photocatalyst was used in the photocatalytic CDC reactions of N-phenyl-tetrahydroisoquinoline (N-phenyl-THIQ) derivatives and dimethyl malonate (Table 2 , 3a–3h ). The desired products were obtained with relatively high conversions (68–92 %). The substituent at the meta-position on the N-phenyl ring exerts a detrimental influence on the conversion of the substrate, which may be attributed to the steric hindrance effect imposed by the meta-position (Table 2, entry 3b). Concurrently, for N-phenyl-tetrahydroisoquinoline (THIQ) derivatives, the electronic effect of the substituent group on the N-phenyl ring significantly modulates the reactivity. As illustrated in Table 2, the incorporation of electron-donating groups (such as CH3 and OCH3) on the N-phenyl ring of tetrahydroisoquinolines markedly accelerates the reaction, thereby yielding products with enhanced conversions (89–92 %; entries 3c, 3d, 3 g). In contrast, the presence of electron-withdrawing groups (such as Cl, Br, and OCF3) on the substrate results in diminished conversions (80–89 %; entries 3e, 3f, 3 h). 3.5 Reusability of the nanofiber photocatalyst The nanofiber NF-GH with better catalytic properties was selected to test its reusability using the CDC reaction between N-phenyltetrahydroisoquinoline and dimethyl malonate as a model reaction. As shown in Fig. 11 (a), the NF-GH nanofiber photocatalyst can be recycled. The CDC reaction can be catalyzed seven times. The results show that the conversion rate decreased from 89.25 % in the first cycle to 83 % in the seventh cycle. In addition, the establishment of the AY184-PHB system is crucial for diminishing the rate at which fluorescence intensity decreases in the nanofiber photocatalyst during catalytic reactions. In the catalytic reaction, the photostability of PVA-PHB nanofibers and AY184-PHB nanofibers is depicted in Fig. 11(b). The fluorescence intensity of AY184-PHB nanofibers showed significantly less decay compared to that of PVA-PHB nanofibers. Furthermore, the NF-GH nanofibers maintained 50 % of their initial fluorescence intensity after 15 hours of cumulative catalytic reaction under light conditions. Fluorescent dyes undergo fading or photobleaching upon prolonged exposure to strong light. This is attributed to the generation of free radicals and singlet oxygen (1O2) under such light conditions. These reactive species attack the chromophores of the dyes, disrupting their chemical structure and resulting in color fading. The introduction of the donor dye AY184 serves two significant functions. Firstly, it enhances the fluorescence intensity of the acceptor PHB. Secondly, AY184 could also react free radicals and singlet oxygen (1O2), thereby hindering the reaction with PHB. This consumption effectively attenuates the destructive effect on the main catalyst PHB. At the same time, the hydrogen bonding network formed between the PVA backbone and the dye PHB as well as the cationic polymer chain also effectively weakened the direct attack of ROS on the chromophore of PHB [44,45]. The synergistic effect between the two effectively improved the photostability and lifetime of the main catalyst PHB. 4 Conclusion In this study, AY184-PHB nanofiber photocatalysts based on the Förster resonance energy transfer (FRET) effect were successfully constructed, and the effective combination of the donor dye C.I. Acid Yellow 184 (AY184) and the acceptor dye phloxine B (PHB) was achieved by four different preparation processes. The optimized nanofibers exhibited significant advantages in both structural and fluorescence properties, especially the NF-TZ nanofibers prepared by co-spinning from the same nozzle process, which showed a FRET efficiency as high as 0.59. These nanofibers exhibited excellent photocatalytic activity in the catalytic cross-dehydrogenation coupling reaction, with the most prominent catalytic performance of the NF-GH nanofibers. In addition, the AY184-PHB nanofibers showed good performance in terms of recycling and photostability. The NF-GH nanofibers could be recycled up to seven times. These results demonstrate that the performance of nanofiber photocatalysts can be effectively enhanced by rational design and preparation process optimization, which provides new ideas and material choices for the application of photocatalytic technology in organic synthesis and other fields. coredata.dc:description: Phloxine B (PHB) demonstrates strong catalytic performance in cross-dehydrogenative coupling (CDC) reactions, yet its light-harvesting efficiency remains limited. Dye-supported nanofiber photocatalysts were developed via electrospinning, integrating polyvinyl alcohol (PVA), polydimethyldiallyl ammonium chloride (PDADMAC), and the Förster resonance energy transfer (FRET) pair: AY184 (donor) and PHB (acceptor). Four strategies—electrospinning-adsorption, blending-electrospinning, co-electrospinning from a single nozzle, and co-electrospinning from separate nozzles—were explored to optimize dye distribution and FRET efficiency. Among the synthesized nanofibers, the NF-TZ, co-electrospun from a single nozzle, showed the highest FRET efficiency at 59 %. The blended-electrospinning nanofibers (NF-GH) exhibited exceptional catalytic activity, achieving nearly 90 % conversion of N-phenyltetrahydroisoquinoline (N-phenyl-THIQ) within 4 hours under the visible light (1 W), and the reaction rate constant is 1.8-fold faster than that for fiber with PHB alone. For NF-GH, the conversion of N-phenyl-THIQ retained to 85 % with reused 7 times, demonstrating robust recyclability and photostability. This finding provides new insight into the construction of recyclable FRET-enhanced photocatalysts with broad spectral response and high energy conversion efficiency for organic photochemical reactions.
coredata.dc:title: Construction of dye-supported fret nanofiber catalysts for photocatalytic Cross-Dehydrogenative coupling reactions
